attributes.title: Hasbro: Growing With Games And Toys
summary: Hasbro has a strong portfolio of brands, both owned and licensed.
Quality company that earns high margins, free cash flow, and returns on capital.
Fourth quarter momentum is strong, following a third quarter earnings beat.
Valuation full, but attractive stock for long-term dividend growth investors.

attributes.content:
Investment Thesis

Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) is a good stock for dividend growth investors as the yield is attractive, it is a quality company strongly positioned financially (free cash flow is consistently positive, even during recessions), and dividends are likely to grow at a nice pace over time. With its strong brands and solid market position, HAS should be able to benefit from these economic tailwinds at its current high margins and return on capital.

For aggressive investors looking to substantially outperform the market, this is not a best idea due to the full valuation, so I wouldn't buy it. However, if I were already holding it, the total return expectation is reasonable enough that I would not sell it. While the current market valuations justify a correction, the stimulative policies of the new administration should drive a pickup in economic growth, which would lead to a strong tailwind of corporate earnings growth.

Background

Hasbro sells toys and games, including both company owned brands and licensed brands, images, and characters. It includes core brands, such as Nerf and Play-Doh, and licensed brands, such as Star Wars, Disney, and Marvel characters.

The company's four largest customers account for around 40% of sales. These are Walmart, Toys R Us and Babies R Us, Target, and Amazon.

Recent Trends

Star Wars: Rogue One is a key influence on fourth quarter sales due to product tie-ins for toys sold. So far the movie appears to be performing solidly and a little better than expected. There are some indications that related toy sales are lagging the success of the movie, but that will not be entirely clear until after the Christmas season.

Disney's Moana also appears to be doing well at the box office, which should also benefit the company's licensed products in the fourth quarter. Disney's Princess also appears to be selling well this season.

Overall, the toy industry appears somewhat weak this holiday season, but Hasbro's portfolio appears to be performing well.

Third Quarter Results

HAS announced earnings that beat consensus by over 16% during the third quarter, earning $2.03 versus $1.74 consensus. Strong sales drove this, particularly from girls' toys and dolls, led by Disney's Princess and Trolls. Games also performed well during the quarter, led by MAGIC.

Despite the earnings beat, keep in mind that the company has beaten consensus most of the time in the last five years, so it is likely that they guide Wall Street conservatively in order to "surprise" on the upside and have more room to work with in case things go wrong.

The main worrying sign was unusually high inventory build. Management attributes this to new product launches, which is in line with strong performance during the quarter. However, there is always the risk of being stuck with too much inventory if management over-estimates demand, leading to a potential for write-downs.

Management indicated that fourth quarter margins may be down year over year due to a variety of investment-oriented spending.

Valuation Opportunity

Forward P/E currently stands at 17.9X, a premium to the company's five-year average of 16.1X, but at somewhat of a discount to the market's ~19X forward multiple. It also trades at a slight premium to its closest competitor, Mattel (MAT)'s, 16.5X forward multiple. It is also a bit high vs. history on an EV/EBITDA basis. Long-term, HAS's forward P/E trading range is around 12-20X.

As we're well into a bull market and most companies are in the upper half of their trading range, we need to look to yield and earnings growth for the bulk of total return potential. To that end, HAS's dividend yield stands at 2.5%, a little above average and in line with the 10-year treasury yield.

Unlike treasuries, however, the dividend is likely to grow with earnings. Consensus estimates have the company's EPS growing at 7% per annum through 2020. Looking back at the company's actual results versus estimated results over the last five years, it looks far more likely to surprise on the upside than on the downside. So using this 7% growth rate appears to be a reasonable base case.

With the 2.5% yield, that suggests a possible 9-10% total return potential per year, which is fairly attractive given the alternatives available at the market's lofty current valuation. Applying a high 20X multiple to 2018 estimated earnings of $4.81 gives a $96 price target, implying over 20% total return potential, including two years of dividends.

However, if the market corrects, a fall toward the low end of the company's trading range (12X forward P/E) implies a downside of over 30%.

So while I don't anticipate a bear market (it seems we never do), it's always important to keep the downside in mind in terms of market exposure and hedging.

Key Risks

  • Manufacturing in China and Mexico. To the degree that the Trump Administration pursues punitive trade policies against manufacturing outsourcing, that would hurt the toy industry, which largely manufactures abroad.
  • Loss of a major retail customer
  • Loss of a major content license

attributes.bio: Avid investor in value, quality growth, and dividend stocks. Focus on finding good businesses that grow value over time, but are cheap for temporary reasons. Prefer companies that use capital wisely, such as in paying out a dividend, repurchasing shares when valuations are attractive, and investing in high-return organic growth opportunities. Generally avoid growth-by-acquisition companies unless there are incredible synergies.
